by Kris Ann Cappelluti
What began as the United
States's largest fund raising
campaign in higher education,
the Campaign for Johns
Hopkins, has neared the
halfway mark of its $450
million goal only a year after
the fund raiser which will
benefit both the University and
the Hospital commenced.
According to Campaign
Chairman Morris W. Offit
('57), the campaign which officially began in September
1984, has received $204 million
in committments from alumni,
foundations, and corporations.

"We entered the Campaign
with a firm confidence and our
expectations have been surpassed" Offit stated. "We
begin the second year of our
five-year effort with 45 percent
of the goal already achieved.
This is a remarkable testament
to the efforts of our volunteer
leadership and the generosity of
our alumni and friends."
To date, the commitments
received include $114 million
from alumni and friends, $49
million from foundations and
other organizations, and $41
million from corporations.
The total amount raised to
date also includes endowments

for eighteen new professional
chairs.

following areas of need as identified by the Hospital and the
University: $150 million for
research and instrumentation;
$100 million in current funding
for academic programs, faculty support and student aid;
$180 million for'construction
renovation; and $120 million
for endowment.

by Ethan Rarick
University President Steven
Muller said Monday he was
"obviously" pleased with the
deal struck two weeks ago
which will allow the university
to expand into part of Wyman
Park.
Muller said the compromise

The compromise was reached

The freshman class held its
first general meeting on
Wednesday, October 30, at
which the officers appointed
chairmen and executive advisors for six committees and
discussed plans for a dance on
November 15 and a semiformal around Valentine's
Day. General announcements
were also made about upcoming campus events and
opportunities.
Bruce Howard, the freshman
class president, summed up the
meeting, saying, "Mostly we
talked about what each of the
different committees was going
to do." He said that the dance
on the fifteenth was the most
important order of business at
the meeting. Since this was the
first meeting, it was primarily
organizational and few other
projects are actually underway
as of yet.
Howard
and
several
chairmen stated that more

committees, particularly in
Education and Publicity.

Committees are currently working on projects involving his

unguarded microphone in the
freshman quad Friday nights,
weeks devoted to such virtues
as safety and non-smoking, and
round-table dinners with
students' faculty advisors are
being considered.
Two more of Howard's campaign planks, provisions for a
campus car rental service and a
university information hotline
for students, have not yet
reached the planning stage. The
car rental plan will be taken up

not a project which the
freshman class would be able to
carry out. The hotline proposal

committees.

New Astrophysics
Center Established
by Greg Kaufman
Johns Hopkins recently announced the establishment of a
new Center for Astrophysical
Sciences under the direction of
Arthur F. Davidsen, professor
of physics and astronomy at
Homewood. At present, the
Center is involved in the
Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope
(HUT) to be launched by the
space shuttle in March, as well
as the Hubble Space Telescope,
which is scheduled for launch in
1986.
Commenting on the new
Center, University president
Steven Muller said, "Johns
Hopkins is now widely
recognized as a leader in
astronomy and astrophysics.
The University is committed to
advancing knowledge in this
field, and the Center for
Astrophysical
Sciences
represents an exciting new stage
in that committment. Arthur
Davidsen is a first-rate scientist
and administrator and has
already begun to assemble a
superb scientific team."
The HUT project is the
largest assignment that is being
undertaken by the new Center.
This joint Hopkins-NASA project is headed by Davidsen, the
principal investigator. The
Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope
will examine sources of
ultraviolet light in various
regions of space.
According to Davidsen,
"HUT is unique because it can
extremely
short
detect
ultraviolet wavelengths and
therefore allows us to see the
whole spectrum." HUT was
conceived, designed, and built
by Hopkins scientists and
engineers at Homewood and
Physics
Applied
the
Laboratory.
Research at the new Center
also includes the study of observations made with the Hubble
Space Telescope. This telescope
will be operated by the Space
Telescope Science Institute, an
independent organization
located at Homewood, made
up of members from 17 different universities. However,
according to Davidsen,
Hopkins and the new Center,
will have preferential access to
the observations made with the
Faint Object Spectrograph Instrument (part of the Hubble
Telescope) which was designed
at the Center.
Once the Hubble Telescope is
in place it will allow scientists
to see up to 7 times farther in
one direction and will increase
our three dimensional view of
the universe 350 times.
Along with space astronomy,
the Center will also be involved
with the study of theoretical
astrophysics, especially examinations of the formation of
start and the energy produced
by quasars. The third major
area of study will be groundbased astronomy, the examination of data from surface
telescopes.
Davidsen commented saying,
"The combination of research
in space astronomy, in groundbased astronomy, and in

theoretical astrophysics should
make the Johns Hopkins
Homewood Campus one of the
most stimulating places in the
world."
According to Davidsen, there
are several opportunities for
undergraduates to participate in
the Center. Many of these positions involve computer programming although there are
limited opportunities in the
astronomical aspects of the
Center for those with experience in the area.
With the advent of the
Center, Davidsen hopes to see,
"an expansion in astrophysics
courses over the next few
years." However, he does not
foresee the development of an
astrophysics major at the
undergraduate level.
There are presently two
astrophysics courses offered by
the physics department.

(CPS)—Increasingly
widespread campus criticism of
President Reagan's Star Wars
program is not having any
noticeable impact on campusbased research for the initiative,
Defense officials say.
About 3,000 higher education researchers submitted
grant proposals to the department's Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI) during the fiscal
year that ended Sept. 30, the
Pentagon reports.
Some 58 grants totaling $14
million were awarded, and in
no case did any researcher offered a grant decline, SDI
public information officer
Mary Pershak says.
Pershak says SDI officials
have had no difficulty finding
university researchers to do the
work they are seeking from the
higher education community.
However, physics professors
on many campuses have been
circulating a petition nationwide to thwart SDI college
research.
"It [the petition drive] hasn't
affected us one bit," Pershak
says. "The proposals keep rolling in."
SDI is the Defense Department agency charged with im-

plementing Reagan's plan to
put lasers and other high-tech
weapons into space to shoot
down nuclear warheads
heading for the U.S.
Critics, who charge Star
Wars is an unworkable and
dangerous escalation of the
arms race, have collected more
than 1,500 signatures from professors and graduate students
pledging not to seek or accept
SDI funds.
University of Illinois physics
professor Michael Weissman,
who helped organize the petition drive during the summer,
says university researchers are
responding to SDI the way one
would expect.
"If I had $3 billion to throw
away, I could find researchers
to do whatever I wanted them
to," Weissman says.

Everyone knows that ARA's food can
be hard to swallow, but until last week
nobody realized their prices were too.
It seems, though, that under certain
(very likely) circumstances, students can
end up paying more for their meals if
they buy the semester-long meal plan
than if they buy their meals individually.
To be precise, if a student buys the
14-meal-a-week plan this spring, he will
have to eat 98.4 percent of his meals to
save money—not very likely considering
that almost everyone misses a meal here
and there.
But wait, it gets better. That figure is
based on someone staying here for Intersession, which doesn't cost any extra
under the meal plan. Since most of the
people on the meal plan are freshmen,
however, few stay here during January.
And if you don't count Intersession, a
student on the 14-meal plan would have
to eat—get this-106.8 percent of his
meals to save any money. How one is
supposed to eat more meals than one has
paid for remains to be explained,
In fairness, we probably ought to mention that the figures are a little more rational for the 19-meal-a-week plan. If
you stay for Intersession on that plan,
for example, you only have to eat 81.1
percent of your meals to save money—
not too difficult. If you don't stay for
Intersession, the figure goes up to 88
percent—a little less likely but not
impossible.

If freshmen were allowed to simply
forego the meal plan, none of this would
be so bad. But in fact all freshmen (and
everybody else living in the dorms, for
that matter) are required to buy one of
the plans, whether they want it or not.
Considering that the university is responsible for that restriction, it is surely also
a responsibility of the administration to
insure a rational plan is offered.
This is all quite important just now
because the current contract with ARA
expires this year. A food committee has
been formed to examine bids from
various companies. So even though

repeating the mistakes of the past. (It

students to be impatient. They are here,

The Atomic Cinematographer: Richard Chisolm
by Sujata Banerjee
When Richard Chisolm takes
the stage in his Atomic Cinema
of course, something funny
happens.
The twenty-eight-year old
cinematographer with long
blond hair and a slight
resemblance to Tom Petty
gestures casually, but strides
with a lanky impatience. He
cracks jokes about the films
and the students, and won't
stop short of a dance contest,
just for the hell of it.
Between laughs, the talk is of
nuclear annihilation, camera
shots, and death. The audience
goes silent as a student tries to
explain what dying would mean
to him. Chisolm relaxes, temporarily. They're on track.
Close to 200 students turn up
each week for his class,
although there is no roll call or
final exam. They come to watch
the movies, and to watch
Chisolm blur the line between
entertainment and reality.
"The topic is real hot,"
Chisolm says, shrugging deeper
into his black leather jacket, as
he tries to explain the course's
success. "The material is very
hardcore because it deals with
a lot of fears people have, or
have tried to deny.. ."
"I've tried to create a free environment with a sense of spontaneity and the present. The less
prepared I am, the better off I
am. I walk in there and there's
a sense of the moment."

The Truth About Where the College Liberals Really Went
by Loren Fox
Who says liberalism is dead?
I have proof that liberals survive and flourish, even if it is in
East Rutherford. My friend
Basil and I, over the past summer, joined a band of idealistic
revolutionaries. I must admit,
though, that I was skeptical
when Basil first came to me
with the idea. "I thought we
were going to Florida," I said,
trying on a pair of sporty
sunglasses. "New Jersey? Are
you sure they're liberals?"
"Are you kidding?" Basil
assured me. "These guys
haven't even seen 'Beverly Hills
Cop'." I knew then that if it
were an iconoclastic group I
was looking for, I had come to
the right place.
These radicals were clever.

No one would ever have
thought to look for a revolutionary's headquarters in the
suburbs. When we got there, we
were greeted by Dmitri, our
leader. There were quick introductions, and I struck up a
conversation with Emily, a
nosy feminist from Bryn Mawr
with long black hair and wire
rimmed glasses."Do you
believe in the E.R.A?" she asked me."Sure," I said. She muttered something that sounded
like "Derivative, totally
derivative" and walked away.
I was in love.
Dmitri gathered us all around
the projection T.V. and revealed the secret demands we would
protest: demands which would
change America forever. "We
want to abolish sales tax on the
necessary foods: meats,

poultry, fruits and all." I looked Dmitri in the eye and broke
the news to him: "There isn't
any tax on those items." When
he heard this, Dmitri frowned
pensively, then shot his arms up
into the air. "Hurrah!" he
roared. That night was spent in
a victory celebration.
During the course of the party I learned a few things. One,
Dmitri's only leadership experience had been as vicepresident of the local Parker
Stevenson fan club. Two, every
one of the liberals besides Basil
and myself had at one time
been members of the Parker
Stevenson fan club. Three,
Emily refused to commit
herself to any emotional involvement so long as the
E.R.A. was ignored. I proposed a number of alternatives to

emotional involvement, the last
of which was answered by a
slap in the face.
Over the next few days we
talked about a new cause to
organize into protests and
rallies. I suggested a protest
against higher education, but it
was thought too conservative.
As the days dragged on, Basil
and I began to have our doubts.
Finally, Basil spoke up. "I
heard somewhere that Parker
Stevenson voted Republican."
There was a violent debate,
and, I must admit, some
shedding of tears, but the outcome was momentous. Dmitri
and ourselves were going to denounce Parker Stevenson and
boycott the East Rutherford
branch of his national fan club.
I suggested writing fiery letters
to the local paper, but it was

thought too conservative. Basil
thought it would be best if we
spray-painted slanderous
remarks about Stevenson on
the sides of buildings. The
group spent two nights doing
this, and I suggested that in
celebration of our victorious
protest we get drunk, but it was
thought too conservative. Basil
ended up leading us in a conga
line around the bonfire.
Liberalism is not dead. And
may it never die, for without it
America would still have the
same values it had fifty years
ago, the rich would get richer
and the poor poorer, and
military strength would be
favored over proper education.
And Emily has asked me to
take her to see "Beverly Hills
Cop." But I thought it too
conservative.

Driven by energetic music

god's body naked in the waves?
The plot is fast-paced and
stimulating, full of ideas and
hints and clues. One gets literally wrapped up in the story,
oblivious to time, delighting in
the ambience and mystique of
Venice in a time none of us
have experienced. Bradbury
creates a time and a place,
populates it with the strangest
people, and begins to scatter the
clues to the wind.
Bradbury is the master
storyteller and he proves it once
more. The imagery he conjures
into one's mind is so clear and
defined that reading is next to
being there. There is not a
thought nor a scene that does
not build towards the climax,
the unveiling of the murderer.
As the writer speaks in the first
person, we are there, on the
pier as the dense fog drifts
through Venice, or answering
the phone on the corner in a
pouring rain. Bradbury pulls all
the right strings, without
leading the reader by the nose,
but by involving the reader, absorbing him or her into the
story.
Ray Bradbury is not limited
as a science fiction writer, he
has been criticised as being untrue to science, but is science
the thing? Of course not, it's
the story, the background is only a framework, a device to
convey the author's ideas.

Bradbury has always used this
to his advantage. His stories are
full of places and backgrounds,
they are the mood creators, the
stage setters but ultimately it is
the plot that makes Bradbury
so distinctive. He combines
genres so well, incorporating
mysticism and the supernatural
with history from the past and
the future.
In Death is a Lonely
Business, Bradbury spins a tale
of detectives, as Daishell Hammett would, in one of is
favorite medums, the murky
past. The title is the key and
one finds it so appropriate at
the end of the novel. And the
key word...Death. It permeates
the book, the death of (the)
people coinciding with the torturous death of the pier. The
screaming rollercoaster grinds
to a halt and falls with twisting
metal. Its twists and bumps and
turns. Its smoothness and then
its terrifying drops. When the
great rollercoaster dies, life
does not. Life always goes on.
The hero, the writer finds hope
and determination, the will to
go on to catch up to the
murderer and stop him, or is it
a her.
The cast of characters is
traditional Bradury, incarnations of good and evil. Bradbury grew up in Waukegan, Illinois and one of his favorites
as a child were the wandering
circuses and gypsy shows. In
many of his stories these people appear, and this one is no
different. The characters are
mostly freaks, such as Fanny,
once a well known soprano, but
now reduced to living in a
chair, eating and singing. Our
narrator, the writer, is an innocent young man with a baby
face. His name is never revealed and one might suggest that
Bradbury has put himself ito
the novel, his own hero. What
further sorcery but to live with
one's own dream characters?
To meet one's childhood idols
and to live in a different land,

the reader is subtly aware of the
fact that Venice, California is
slowly enveloping him. Bradbury's use of the first person
completes the effect. The
characters run the gamut, from
paranoid to overbearing, quiet
and shy to aggressive and confident. A spectrum of people to
love and to hate is represented.
Bradbury has brought
together so many elements that
it seems somewhat overwhelming. At points it may seem too
detailed, for every crack in the
cement is there, every piercing
cry of the banshee. If one reads
while half asleep much of the
detail glosses along and is
quickly forgotten. So much is
packed into 278 pages of novel
that a few hours is not enough
time to absorb it all. Bradbury's
use of metaphors and similes is
exquisite and expert, but can be
confusing. There lies my single
complaint, the choking feeling
of being crushed by images.
Death is a Lonely Business is
a novel written on several levels
and thus can be read on several
levels. It's deeper than it may
seem, but taken straightforwardly it is still a fun detective
story, suitable for children. It's
also a look at people, scared
people and willful people, people that become so real one
feels that one knows them. The
novel is also a love story, a
story of love between people, of
love for people and love for
ideas and dreams and the truth.
It is sure to delight all, from
the staunch worldwide Bradbury fans to the new reader.
The old fan will recognize
Bradbury's talent and style in
the novel while new readers will
discover a gripping story with
a different light. Death is a
Lonely Business is a fun book
to read, it encompasses all the
emotions and is presented in a
fashion that one can sink fangs
into. Bradbury never, and I
mean never, ceases to entertain.

by Miriam Tucker
No, you're not imagining
things. Something is different
about the single service lane on
Charles Street, other than its
direction of traffic. The southbound lane, which extends
from University Parkway to
29th Street, sparkles because
it's made of glasphalt.
According to James L. Kapplin of the Department of
Public Works, glasphalt was
born out of the environmental
movement of the late 1960's. It
was one of many attempts to
recycle waste products, such as
tin cans, newspapers, and, in
this case, glass. Regular streets
are paved with a mixture of
asphalt (which is derived from
petroleum), sand, and other
components. Stone is added as
an "aggregate," which is essential for binding the mixture
together. In glasphalt, crushed
glass replaces 30 to 40 percent
of this aggregate.
The first street in Baltimore
resurfaced with glasphalt was
the length of Charles between
Lexington and Saratoga Streets,
downtown. this stretch was
paved in 1971, at the suggestion
of Mayor Schaefer. Since then,
seventeen street sections have

been repaved with glasphalt in
Baltimore. The lane in front of
the MSE was done in September of 1984. Other cities, including New York, have also
used glasphalt in the past fifteen years.
Glasphalt is used only on
main and secondary roads. It is
not used on residential streets,
for safety reasons. On busy
streets, such as Charles, the
glass chips on the surface are
worn down within hours by the
heavy traffic flow. On quiet
residential streets, however, it
was feared that children playing in the street may be cut by
loose pieces of glass, before car
tires could smooth down the
surface.
Although glasphalt was first
used for conservation, it is continued now purely for
aesthetics. While citizens
brought an excess of glass bottles to landfills for recycling in
the early 1970's, now there is a
shortage. In order to use the
glass in the asphalt, it must first
be "cleaned." This procedure
involves removing, by hand, all
-the pieces of metal and paper
labels from the bottles. Furthermore, only the opaque glass is
used in glasphalt; clear glass is
recycled by the bottling com-

panies. Thus, although glasphalt was originally intended to
save money on the stone aggregate, which must be mined,
it ends up costing ten to fifteen
dollars more per ton. One ton
of asphalt translates into 18
square yards of pavement, one
inch thick. Therefore, since
several tons are needed to cover
a two-to-three block area,
glasphalt is certainly not the
most economical way of paving
a street. An exception to this

rule exists in the southern
United States, where stone is in
short supply. Since stone must
be shipped to the south from
the northeast, the cost of
regular asphalt may be equal
to, or even more than, the cost
of glasphalt.
So, why use glasphalt in
Baltimore? In short, because it
looks nice. It is much more
cheerful to drive at night down
a bright, sparkling street than
a dull, gray asphalt one. Other

than the cost, there are no
disadvantages to glasphalt. It
wears just well as regular
asphalt, it doesn't get any more
slippery in snow or rain, and is
no more prone to potholes. According to Kapplin, one or two
streets will be done each year in
Baltimore, as the supply of
glass permits. Perhaps in ten
years, when we come back to
visit Hopkins, we may find that
all the streets leading here are
sparkling.

funds.

eating habits and how the

300 years has affected the
development of convenience
foods.

Sherry Gill, Director of the Office of Special Events, Mintz introduced his talk as really an
afterthought to the more
historical perspective of his
book.

larger changes in society,"

the wholesale alteration of
American eating habits. He
added "Over one-third of every
food dollar is spent on food
consumed outside the home,
and the total national amount
spent in eating establishments

last 16 years."

variety of prepared foods to be
eaten in the home is increasing
as well. "You can buy Veal
Oreganata, and Veal Marsala in
Diet Gourmet sections of the

frozen food aisle of your
favorite supermarket and both
taste exactly the same."
The increased consumption
of sugar, he continued, is a
reflection of the addition of
more and more processed foods

commented, noting that purchase of processed items such
as soft drinks have risen 78 percent in the last few years. "It's
a wonder why Wienberger left
his job at Pepsi-Cola to take a
little job in the Defense Department," Mintz remarked.
The reason that consumption
of sugar parallels consumption
of processed foods, Mintz said,

(cane, beet or corn) is used in

available. "Sugar is even used

foods, and even helps in the
"go-away" of peanut butter—
the more sugar in the peanut
butter, the less it sticks to the
roof of your mouth.
It's all a reflection of the
perceived "pressure" of not
enough time in our society,
Mintz said, noting that "We
combine consumptions—
popcorn with a movie, drihking

foods, Mintz concluded, add to

Being A Premed
Hard to Swallow
But Not a Student

Everyone knows that ARA's food can
be hard to swallow, but until last week
nobody realized their prices were too.
It seems, though, that under certain
(very likely) circumstances, students can
end up paying more for their meals if
they buy the semester-long meal plan
than if they buy their meals individually.
To be precise, if a student buys the
14-meal-a-week plan this spring, he will
have to eat 98.4 percent of his meals to
save money—not very likely considering
that almost everyone misses a meal here
and there.
But wait, it gets better. That figure is
based on someone staying here for Intersession, which doesn't cost any extra
under the meal plan. Since most of the
people on the meal plan are freshmen,
however, few stay here during January.
And if you don't count Intersession, a
student on the 14-meal plan would have
to eat—get this-106.8 percent of his
meals to save any money. How one is
supposed to eat more meals than one has
paid for remains to be explained,
In fairness, we probably ought to mention that the figures are a little more rational for the 19-meal-a-week plan. If
you stay for Intersession on that plan,
for example, you only have to eat 81.1
percent of your meals to save money—
not too difficult. If you don't stay for
Intersession, the figure goes up to 88
percent—a little less likely but not
impossible.

If freshmen were allowed to simply
forego the meal plan, none of this would
be so bad. But in fact all freshmen (and
everybody else living in the dorms, for
that matter) are required to buy one of
the plans, whether they want it or not.
Considering that the university is responsible for that restriction, it is surely also
a responsibility of the administration to
insure a rational plan is offered.
This is all quite important just now
because the current contract with ARA
expires this year. A food committee has
been formed to examine bids from
various companies. So even though
students will apparently have to suffer
through the spring semester with a
ridiculous meal plan, perhaps the situation can be remedied for next year. In
particular (and in ascending order of
authority), Bettye Miller, director of auxilliary enterprises, Norman Krueger,
associate dean for administrative services, and Robert Welch, dean of administration, should be careful to avoid
repeating the mistakes of the past. (It
might also be noted that it is Miller and
Krueger who are chiefly responsible for
the current nonsense.)
There can be no argument that this
year's meal plan has labored under a
ludicrous pricing scheme. There isn't
much that can be done about that now,
but the administration ought to make
sure that a little common sense is
employed in the future.

Snap Judgements
There is a tendency on the part of
students to be impatient. They are here,
after all, only four years, and so they
often rush to rather quick judgements.
That is certainly true of new administrators. When George Fisher was
appointed Dean of the School of Arts
and Sciences three years ago, students interested in such things were already calling him a failure or a success(depending
on their views) by the end of the first
semester. That's certainly understandable, but it's equally regrettable. It really takes at least two years in any new job
to get to know your way around the
place.(That isn't to say that nothing can
be accomplished in the first few months
of a new dean's tenure; merely that a
thorough analysis of how good a dean,
or provost, or president, so-and-so has
been can only be reached after an examination of his performance over
several years.)
Unfortunately, people seem to be
making the same snap judgements now
with the newest dean—Robert Welch,
the dean of administration. Already,
some folks are arguing about how good
a job he has done. That fact is, though,
that no one has any idea how well Welch
will do his job (or, for that matter, how
well the new structure of which he is the
major component will function). But
while it's too soon to form an opinion
on Welch, people ought to keep an eye

on him, for rarely has a rookie been
thrown so many interesting issues. Those
issues were on display at a recent Student
Council meeting, when Welch talked
with the council on a variety of things.
In particular, student housing poses a
major problem for Welch. The university plans to renovate (and possibly expand) its current housing, and exactly
what those renovations ought to entail
remains an open question. The issue
clearly goes beyond technical questions
of when the renovations ought to be
done and what the refurbished buildings
ought to look like. The university has a
chance to change the nature of student
housing at Hopkins. Should the new versions of Wolman and McCoy be closer
to traditional dormitories, for example?
On an even more general level, should
university-owned housing present a more
collegiate atmosphere? (We're by no
means suggesting that it should; we'll
withhold judgement on that for a while.
We're just pointing out that a rare opportunity exists to address these
questions.)
Welch also has several other major
problems to deal with—renovations of
Gilman, admissions problems and financial aid questions all come to mind. Considering he has been at Hopkins less than
four months, dealing with those issues
is a lot to ask. How Welch does the rest
of the year should prove interesting.

The Truth About Where the College Liberals Really Went
by Loren Fox
Who says liberalism is dead?
I have proof that liberals survive and flourish, even if it is in
East Rutherford. My friend
Basil and I, over the past summer, joined a band of idealistic
revolutionaries. I must admit,
though, that I was skeptical
when Basil first came to me
with the idea. "I thought we
were going to Florida," I said,
trying on a pair of sporty
sunglasses. "New Jersey? Are
you sure they're liberals?"
"Are you kidding?" Basil
assured me. "These guys
haven't even seen 'Beverly Hills
Cop'." I knew then that if it
were an iconoclastic group I
was looking for, I had come to
the right place.
These radicals were clever.

No one would ever have
thought to look for a revolutionary's headquarters in the
suburbs. When we got there, we
were greeted by Dmitri, our
leader. There were quick introductions, and I struck up a
conversation with Emily, a
nosy feminist from Bryn Mawr
with long black hair and wire
rimmed glasses."Do you
believe in the E.R.A?" she asked me."Sure," I said. She muttered something that sounded
like "Derivative, totally
derivative" and walked away.
I was in love.
Dmitri gathered us all around
the projection T.V. and revealed the secret demands we would
protest: demands which would
change America forever. "We
want to abolish sales tax on the
necessary foods: meats,

poultry, fruits and all." I looked Dmitri in the eye and broke
the news to him: "There isn't
any tax on those items." When
he heard this, Dmitri frowned
pensively, then shot his arms up
into the air. "Hurrah!" he
roared. That night was spent in
a victory celebration.
During the course of the party I learned a few things. One,
Dmitri's only leadership experience had been as vicepresident of the local Parker
Stevenson fan club. Two, every
one of the liberals besides Basil
and myself had at one time
been members of the Parker
Stevenson fan club. Three,
Emily refused to commit
herself to any emotional involvement so long as the
E.R.A. was ignored. I proposed a number of alternatives to

emotional involvement, the last
of which was answered by a
slap in the face.
Over the next few days we
talked about a new cause to
organize into protests and
rallies. I suggested a protest
against higher education, but it
was thought too conservative.
As the days dragged on, Basil
and I began to have our doubts.
Finally, Basil spoke up. "I
heard somewhere that Parker
Stevenson voted Republican."
There was a violent debate,
and, I must admit, some
shedding of tears, but the outcome was momentous. Dmitri
and ourselves were going to denounce Parker Stevenson and
boycott the East Rutherford
branch of his national fan club.
I suggested writing fiery letters
to the local paper, but it was

thought too conservative. Basil
thought it would be best if we
spray-painted slanderous
remarks about Stevenson on
the sides of buildings. The
group spent two nights doing
this, and I suggested that in
celebration of our victorious
protest we get drunk, but it was
thought too conservative. Basil
ended up leading us in a conga
line around the bonfire.
Liberalism is not dead. And
may it never die, for without it
America would still have the
same values it had fifty years
ago, the rich would get richer
and the poor poorer, and
military strength would be
favored over proper education.
And Emily has asked me to
take her to see "Beverly Hills
Cop." But I thought it too
conservative.

Martin Scorsese's After
Hours is a quality piece of
mindless entertainment; there
are certainly no cerebral
challenges to be found here, but
this may be the best "leave your
brain at the door" type of picture to come along in some
time. While one might expect
Martin Scorsese, director of
Taxi Driver and Raging Bull to
produce a film of more
substance, the film should not
be seen as a failure: After
Hours succeeds on its own
terms, even though these terms
may not be among Scorsese's
more ambitious ones.
The story is about one evening in the life of Paul Hackett
(Griffin Dunne), a word processor somewhat unsatisfied
with his lot in life. While this
particular evening may be extraordinary for the hero, it is
doubtful that this string of
disasters is the change of pace
Hackett had in mind.
After work, in a New York
coffee shop, Dunne meets Roseanna Arquette (best. known
for her role in Desperately

Seeking Susan), and he even
manages to get her number.
Unfortunately, he thinks, his
pen won't write at the most
vital of times. But Dunne just
cannot leave well enough alone
and accept this omen for what
it is. He calls Arquette that
evening and arranges a date for
still later that night.
All Dunne has in his wallet is
a $20 bill (a la Easy Bank),
which flies out the window during his cab ride to SoHo, leaving Dunne nearly penniless in a
neighborhood far from his
own. And the more Dunne
finds out about Arquette, the
weirder things seem to get: she's
separated from a man whose
obsession with The Wizard of
Oz spills over into bedroom activity, she seems to be undergoing treatment for some type of
severe burns, and she can barely hold the same line of conversation for more than one
sentence at a time. Arquette's
roommate, a leather-clad
sculptress played by Linda
Fiorentino, specializes in making plaster of Paris bagels with
cream cheese, and is currently
hard at work on her latest

endeavor, a paper mache model
of a man screaming out in
agony. When things just get too
weird for Hackett, he runs out
on Arquette, and proceeds to
run into Terri Garr who plays
a 60's-obsessed waitress, lava
lamp, bee-hive hairdo and all,
at the sleazy Terminal Bar, and
into Cheech and Chong who
play twO robbers who seem to
clean out every apartment in
SoHo before the night is
through.
But run away as he might,
Hackett simply cannot escape
the SoHo streets (the 97' in his
pocket just doesn't cover the
newly-raised $1.50 subway fare,
the fare having been raised as
of midnight that night), and as
a result he finds himself:
responsible for a suicide; on the
receiving end of a mohawk
haircut; accused of Cheech and
Chong's robberies; pursued by
a Mister Softee ice cream truck;
trapped inside a piece of
modern art; and the butt of
what seems to be hundreds of
other coincidences, all worse
than the last.
After Hours maintains a high
level of comedy throughout this

string of coincidences; the ideas
behind much of the action are
very funny to begin with, and
the talent of the cast serves to
make these moments even funnier. Hackett is especially good,
as he manages to retain the
sympathy of the audience even
when his desire for a cheap one
night stand, and the cruelty of
his rejection of Arquette are
obvious to the viewer.
But, unfortunately, After
Hours never rises above being
simply a string a bad luck and
coincidences. The events
depicted in After Hours seem to
pile up one on top of the other
rather than heading in a particular direction that would give
the film a true structure. As it
stands, After Hours is just a
bunch of events lacking
something, just one climaxing
event, which can serve to tie it
all together. Perhaps the film's
final coincidence is the one
where the viewer is meant to see
everything fall together, since

the main character has come
full circle, but there just isn't
enough build-up to this coincidence to indicate that it is the
culmination of the evening. As
presented by Scorsese, this final
event is just one more ordinary
link in the chain.
Still, the film's high comedy
and cleverly thought-out action
is enough to save this film from
its own plotlessness. And much
of the camera work and editing
used in the first half is also
highly inventive and entertaining (a speeded-up cab ride, a
gracefully floating $20 bill, keys
dropped from a building falling
directly into the camera, and
others), even if such work is
conspicuously absent in the
film's second half. It's best not
to ponder After Hours's flaws,
though; if you turn off your
mind and just enjoy all the
laughs of this definitely bizarre
movie, After Hours will leave
you satisfied.

Mystery and Love: Bradbury Does it Again
DEATH IS A LONELY BUSINESS

by Lucian Chen
Death Is A Lonely Business
by Ray Bradbury. Alfred A.
Knopf, Inc.
$15.95. 278 pages.
Ray Bradbury has been tagged as "The World's Greatest
Living Science Fiction Writer."
The title does not begin to
describe his breadth. His new
detective novel, Death is a
Lonely Business, is a full length
thriller-mystery-supernaturaldetective story, and that's quite
a mouthful, which Bradbury
pulls off with his characteristic
flair. This novel is his first since
Something Wicked This Way
Comes was published in 1962.
(I own a first printing in case

you're interested in offering a
million dollars for it) but still
exhibits his trademarks. At the
fore is his descriptive imagery,
his developed characters, an involving plot and of course
pages chock full of lovable
eccentrics.
The novel is set in Venice,
California, in 1949, as the
waterfront amusement park is
being torn down. The hero is a
struggling young writer who
sells his stories every now and
then to pulp magazines, much
like Bradbury himself did a few
ages ago. One foggy haunted
night the writer discovers a
body in the canal, beckoning to
him from inside an abandoned
lion cage. It is only the beginning, as more deaths tumble out

from the run down houses of
Venice. From Fanny Florianna
the 380 pound diva, to the
thousand year old lady across
town, who sold canaries a
generation ago.
The writer turned detective
meets up with Elmo Crumley,
a police detective who unfolds
into a many faceted man and
together they begin to investigate the deaths, or are they
murders? They seem accidental, but then why is someone
haunting the two, with
seaweed? Why is Henry the
blind man standing watch?
Why is the ugly man with the
god's body naked in the waves?
The plot is fast-paced and
stimulating, full of ideas and
hints and clues. One gets literally wrapped up in the story,
oblivious to time, delighting in
the ambience and mystique of
Venice in a time none of us
have experienced. Bradbury
creates a time and a place,
populates it with the strangest
people, and begins to scatter the
clues to the wind.
Bradbury is the master
storyteller and he proves it once
more. The imagery he conjures
into one's mind is so clear and
defined that reading is next to
being there. There is not a
thought nor a scene that does
not build towards the climax,
the unveiling of the murderer.
As the writer speaks in the first
person, we are there, on the
pier as the dense fog drifts
through Venice, or answering
the phone on the corner in a
pouring rain. Bradbury pulls all
the right strings, without
leading the reader by the nose,
but by involving the reader, absorbing him or her into the
story.
Ray Bradbury is not limited
as a science fiction writer, he
has been criticised as being untrue to science, but is science
the thing? Of course not, it's
the story, the background is only a framework, a device to
convey the author's ideas.

Bradbury has always used this
to his advantage. His stories are
full of places and backgrounds,
they are the mood creators, the
stage setters but ultimately it is
the plot that makes Bradbury
so distinctive. He combines
genres so well, incorporating
mysticism and the supernatural
with history from the past and
the future.
In Death is a Lonely
Business, Bradbury spins a tale
of detectives, as Daishell Hammett would, in one of is
favorite medums, the murky
past. The title is the key and
one finds it so appropriate at
the end of the novel. And the
key word...Death. It permeates
the book, the death of (the)
people coinciding with the torturous death of the pier. The
screaming rollercoaster grinds
to a halt and falls with twisting
metal. Its twists and bumps and
turns. Its smoothness and then
its terrifying drops. When the
great rollercoaster dies, life
does not. Life always goes on.
The hero, the writer finds hope
and determination, the will to
go on to catch up to the
murderer and stop him, or is it
a her.
The cast of characters is
traditional Bradury, incarnations of good and evil. Bradbury grew up in Waukegan, Illinois and one of his favorites
as a child were the wandering
circuses and gypsy shows. In
many of his stories these people appear, and this one is no
different. The characters are
mostly freaks, such as Fanny,
once a well known soprano, but
now reduced to living in a
chair, eating and singing. Our
narrator, the writer, is an innocent young man with a baby
face. His name is never revealed and one might suggest that
Bradbury has put himself ito
the novel, his own hero. What
further sorcery but to live with
one's own dream characters?
To meet one's childhood idols
and to live in a different land,

the reader is subtly aware of the
fact that Venice, California is
slowly enveloping him. Bradbury's use of the first person
completes the effect. The
characters run the gamut, from
paranoid to overbearing, quiet
and shy to aggressive and confident. A spectrum of people to
love and to hate is represented.
Bradbury has brought
together so many elements that
it seems somewhat overwhelming. At points it may seem too
detailed, for every crack in the
cement is there, every piercing
cry of the banshee. If one reads
while half asleep much of the
detail glosses along and is
quickly forgotten. So much is
packed into 278 pages of novel
that a few hours is not enough
time to absorb it all. Bradbury's
use of metaphors and similes is
exquisite and expert, but can be
confusing. There lies my single
complaint, the choking feeling
of being crushed by images.
Death is a Lonely Business is
a novel written on several levels
and thus can be read on several
levels. It's deeper than it may
seem, but taken straightforwardly it is still a fun detective
story, suitable for children. It's
also a look at people, scared
people and willful people, people that become so real one
feels that one knows them. The
novel is also a love story, a
story of love between people, of
love for people and love for
ideas and dreams and the truth.
It is sure to delight all, from
the staunch worldwide Bradbury fans to the new reader.
The old fan will recognize
Bradbury's talent and style in
the novel while new readers will
discover a gripping story with
a different light. Death is a
Lonely Business is a fun book
to read, it encompasses all the
emotions and is presented in a
fashion that one can sink fangs
into. Bradbury never, and I
mean never, ceases to entertain.

Glasphalt: All That Glitters is not Gold
by Miriam Tucker
No, you're not imagining
things. Something is different
about the single service lane on
Charles Street, other than its
direction of traffic. The southbound lane, which extends
from University Parkway to
29th Street, sparkles because
it's made of glasphalt.
According to James L. Kapplin of the Department of
Public Works, glasphalt was
born out of the environmental
movement of the late 1960's. It
was one of many attempts to
recycle waste products, such as
tin cans, newspapers, and, in
this case, glass. Regular streets
are paved with a mixture of
asphalt (which is derived from
petroleum), sand, and other
components. Stone is added as
an "aggregate," which is essential for binding the mixture
together. In glasphalt, crushed
glass replaces 30 to 40 percent
of this aggregate.
The first street in Baltimore
resurfaced with glasphalt was
the length of Charles between
Lexington and Saratoga Streets,
downtown. this stretch was
paved in 1971, at the suggestion
of Mayor Schaefer. Since then,
seventeen street sections have

been repaved with glasphalt in
Baltimore. The lane in front of
the MSE was done in September of 1984. Other cities, including New York, have also
used glasphalt in the past fifteen years.
Glasphalt is used only on
main and secondary roads. It is
not used on residential streets,
for safety reasons. On busy
streets, such as Charles, the
glass chips on the surface are
worn down within hours by the
heavy traffic flow. On quiet
residential streets, however, it
was feared that children playing in the street may be cut by
loose pieces of glass, before car
tires could smooth down the
surface.
Although glasphalt was first
used for conservation, it is continued now purely for
aesthetics. While citizens
brought an excess of glass bottles to landfills for recycling in
the early 1970's, now there is a
shortage. In order to use the
glass in the asphalt, it must first
be "cleaned." This procedure
involves removing, by hand, all
-the pieces of metal and paper
labels from the bottles. Furthermore, only the opaque glass is
used in glasphalt; clear glass is
recycled by the bottling com-

panies. Thus, although glasphalt was originally intended to
save money on the stone aggregate, which must be mined,
it ends up costing ten to fifteen
dollars more per ton. One ton
of asphalt translates into 18
square yards of pavement, one
inch thick. Therefore, since
several tons are needed to cover
a two-to-three block area,
glasphalt is certainly not the
most economical way of paving
a street. An exception to this

rule exists in the southern
United States, where stone is in
short supply. Since stone must
be shipped to the south from
the northeast, the cost of
regular asphalt may be equal
to, or even more than, the cost
of glasphalt.
So, why use glasphalt in
Baltimore? In short, because it
looks nice. It is much more
cheerful to drive at night down
a bright, sparkling street than
a dull, gray asphalt one. Other

than the cost, there are no
disadvantages to glasphalt. It
wears just well as regular
asphalt, it doesn't get any more
slippery in snow or rain, and is
no more prone to potholes. According to Kapplin, one or two
streets will be done each year in
Baltimore, as the supply of
glass permits. Perhaps in ten
years, when we come back to
visit Hopkins, we may find that
all the streets leading here are
sparkling.
